description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: On 13 March the Minister of Health in Iceland announced about ban on gatherings and closures of schools. Starting on March 16, 2020, the operations of primary schools and preschools would be limited according to strict measures (limiting class sizes and maintaining space between students); universities and junior colleges will be closed across the country, the courses will be taught online.

description: Starting on August 14th, 2020 rules on social distancing will be eased for colleges, universities, according to a new announcement issued by Svandís Svavarsdóttir, Minister of Health. Colleges and universities will be allowed to maintain one-meter social distance between individuals without face masks. Common equipment and surfaces shall be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis placed on personal hygienic measures and individual responsibility.

description: Starting on August 14th, 2020 rules on social distancing will be eased for colleges, universities, according to a new announcement issued by Svandís Svavarsdóttir, Minister of Health. Otherwise, the general rule of the two-meter social distancing between individuals still applies. In circumstances where the two-meter distance cannot be maintained face masks should be worn. Colleges and universities will be allowed to maintain one-meter social distance between individuals without face masks. Common equipment and surfaces shall be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis placed on personal hygienic measures and individual responsibility. UPDATE: Starting on August 21, 2020, in all secondary school and university buildings, social distancing of 1 meter between individuals should be applied. In situations where the principle of intimacy cannot be enforced, such as practical teaching, art education and clinical learning, a face mask covering the mouth and nose should be worn. Both teachers and students should wear a mask.

description:
Starting on August 21, 2020, in all secondary school buildings, social distancing of 1 meter between individuals should be applied. In situations where the principle of intimacy cannot be enforced, such as practical teaching, art education and clinical learning, a face mask covering the mouth and nose should be worn. Both teachers and students should wear a mask. Educational processes shall be organized so that each student interacts with as few as possible. Students should be distributed to permanent entrances to a school building as far as possible and corridors shall be a travel space. Permanent groups and classes should be avoided as far as possible mixing with other students. All non-teaching events should be cancelled. 
Common equipment/contact surfaces should be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis should also be placed on individual antiseptic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: According to the policy on August 21, 2020, the rules on mass limits and proximity limits do not apply to children born in 2005 and later. Preschools (i.e. kindergartens) maintain school work on a condition that staff who are involved in school buildings may have at least a 1-metre proximity restriction between themselves without the use of face masks. Only one parent may accompany a child on a condition that they do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and they shall observe at least a 1 meter proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Preschool administration may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees and parents entering kindergartens, such as for freight, care should be taken to a 2-metre proximity restriction. Disinfection measures should be taken after each day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
According to the announcement of the Minister of Health on October 7, 2020, new stricter restrictions are applied to the metropolitan area. 
Despite the general closure of swimming pools school swimming lessons are permitted for children born in or after 2005. Sports, youth and leisure activities are also permitted for them. UPDATE: New regulations announced on October 21, 2020, state that all sports and leisure activities for children of pre-school and junior-school age, including school swimming lessons, which involve physical contact, are prohibited. Other activities that do not involve physical contact are permitted. All sports and leisure activities that do not involve mixing between groups and takes place in the classroom, e.g. breaktime activities or physical education classes in schools, are therefore permitted.

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Preschools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter the sshool building unless it is necessary. For adjustment periods the presence of a single parent (and only) parent for a child must be organised such that parents do not use common equipment in the school and they must maintain the 2-metre social distancing rule among themselves and between themselves and employees. School management may require parents to wear masks. Disinfection should be taken after each day.

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings in Iceland remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Secondary schools may continue schoolwork on condition that students and staff can maintain at least 2 metre social distancing. Mixing students between groups is forbidden but teachers and employesses are allowed to go between groups. The restriction on the number of people, or mixing groups may be departed in shared premises as entrance, foyes, and restrooms if face masks are used. Under specific circumstances (practical classes, art classes), students and teachers must use face masks. Non-teaching events should be banned. Physical contact is permitted only during sports training sessions and competitions but in changing rooms 2 metres distance should be kept. Share contact surfaces/equipment needs to be disinfected daily.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Preschools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter the sshool building unless it is necessary. For adjustment periods the presence of a single parent (and only) parent for a child must be organised such that parents do not use common equipment in the school and they must maintain the 2-metre social distancing rule among themselves and between themselves and employees. The 2-metre social distancing rule does not apply to pre-school children. Whenever the social distancing is not possible to keep, the fase masks must be worn. Sports, youth and leisure events for children/pre-school age are prohibited either inside or outside the pre-school premises.

The restriction on the number of people, or mixing groups may be departed in shared premises as entrance, foyes, and restrooms if face masks are used. Under specific circumstances (practical classes, art classes), students and teachers must use face masks. Non-teaching events should be banned. Physical contact is permitted only during sports training sessions and competitions but in changing rooms 2 metres distance should be kept. Share contact surfaces/equipment needs to be disinfected daily. UPDATE: The policy ended on November 2, 2020, the guidance about the maximum amount of people allowed to gather became different for different years of secondary school.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Primary schools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. This regulations are applied to after school centres, community centres and sports activities in primary schools. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter school buildings except when absolutely necessary. Disinfection should be taken after each day. UPDATE: The policy was ended on November 02, 2020, when the Icelandic government started to give different guidelines for the different junior school levels.

description: According to the new regulations on October 21st, 2020, in metropolitan area, all sports and leisure activities for children of pre-school (kindergarten) age and junior-school age, including school swimming lessons, which involve physical contact, are prohibited. Sports and leisure activities that do not involve physical contact are permitted. All sports and leisure activities that do not involve mixing between groups over and above that which takes place in the classroom, e.g. breaktime activities or physical education classes in schools, are therefore permitted. Gatherings are limited to 20 people, and the distance of 2 meters should be applied. During the sessions participants may not exchange equipment and all equipment shall be disinfected between sessions. Usage of shared equipments are prohibited.

description:
On November 02, 2020, new regulations for primary level schools.
Grades 1–4: Pupils are exempted from the 2-metre social distancing rule and are not required to wear face masks. Social gathering limit is 50 people. The same rules apply for after-school leisure centres for children in Grades 1-4.
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. The rules on group sizes and mixing of groups may be set aside in common areas in schools, providing that pupils in Grades 5–10, and the staff, wear face masks. Staff are permitted to move between groups and limit of gathering is 10 people. Staff needs to keep distance rule of 2 metres. Social events, sport activities are prohibited.
Pupil are exempted of mask wearing and 2 metres distance rules.

description:
On November 02, 2020, new regulations for primary level schools.
Grades 1–4: Pupils are exempted from the 2-metre social distancing rule and are not required to wear face masks. Social gathering limit is 50 people. The same rules apply for after-school leisure centres for children in Grades 1-4.
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. description: On November 2, 2020 announcement, the maximum number of people is 25 for the first year of school at the upper secondary schools; and 10 for upper secondary schools, universities and music schools. The distance rule and the usage of face masks rule remain the same. Mixing of groups of students is not permitted during teaching; teaching and other staff may, however, move between groups. In specific cases (practical classes, art teaching and clinical training) when the distance can not be kept, both teachers and students should wear face masks. UPDATE: As of November 18, 2020, personalised services that require closer contact than two metres are allowed again, with mandatory face masks. Students in upper secondary schools, universities (usually ages 16 to 20) can gather in groups of up to 25 (including staff), instead of the previous limit of 10. Staff and students must still wear face masks whenever it is not possible to maintain the two-metre rule.

description: Iceland Minister of Health on November 20, 2020, announced that music schools are permitted to conduct individual lessons with a 2-metre proximity restriction between staff and students. In case when the distance rule cannot be applied, both students and employees shall wear a face mask. The maximum number will be comparable to that in primary schools; 25 for the older students, i.e. in grades 5-10 and 50 for younger students. The two-metre rule applies to students in grades 8-10, but if it needs to be deviated from, face masks should be used. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Non-employees who come to music schools, such as for freight, shall wear face masks. Buildings should be disinfected after each day.

description: Under new regulations from the Minister of Health on December 22, 2020, some relaxations will be made in the measures against Covid-19 applying in schools and universities in the new year. In pre-schools and junior schools up to 20 staff may occupy the same area, and may move between groups. The distance rule remains the same (2 meters), whenever it can not be kept, face masks should be worn. In junior schools, in shared areas (canteens), the number restrictions may be ignored, providing that staff use face-masks. These rules will also apply to after-school activity centres, organised sports events, youth activities and leisure activities, and to the operations of social centres. In upper-secondary schools gathering ban is up to 30 pupils and staff may occupy the same area. Pupils may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. In universities gathering ban is up to 50 students and staff may occupy each teaching or study area. Mixing between these groups of students will not be permitted, though staff may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. Music lessons for children in pre-schools and junior school are permitted, observing the same rules as apply to each school level respectively. For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

These rules will also apply to after-school activity centres, organised sports events, youth activities and leisure activities, and to the operations of social centres. In upper-secondary schools gathering ban is up to 30 pupils and staff may occupy the same area. Pupils may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. In universities gathering ban is up to 50 students and staff may occupy each teaching or study area. Mixing between these groups of students will not be permitted, though staff may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. Music lessons for children in pre-schools and junior school are permitted, observing the same rules as apply to each school level respectively. For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.

description:
Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. The policy will take effect from March 25, 2021 and shall remain in force up to 31 March 2021. Preschools may maintain school work in school buildings with a 2-metre proximity limit between staff. Whenever the social distance of 2 metres cannot be ensured, masks shouls be worn. Employees are not obliged to wear face masks when communicating with preschoolers. There should be no more than 10 adults in each space. Children are exempt from mass gathering and social distancing limitations. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Adaptation periods should be organized in a way that parents do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and keep at least a 2-metre proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Only one parent accompanies the child in an adjustment.
Preschool administrators may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees entering kindergartens (i.e. service staff, freight) should keep 2-metre proximity restriction and wear face masks.

description:
The Minister of Health, the Ministry of Education, Science and Culture on March 31, 2021 announced regulations regarding the operation of schools. Starting from April 1 through April 15, the following regulations in colleges are applied:
The maximum number of students and staff in a space is 30. A 2-metre proximity restriction should be maintained between students and staff, but a mask should be worn otherwise. The mixing of students between groups is permitted and staff are allowed to move between spaces. Events related to work or social life in secondary school shall be governed by the provisions on performing arts in the Regulation on restrictions on epidemic gatherings.

description:
The Minister of Health, the Ministry of Education, Science and Culture on March 31, 2021 announced regulations regarding the operation of schools. Starting from April 1 through April 15, the following regulations in primary schools are applied:
The maximum number of students is 50 and mixing between groups within the same school is permitted. The maximum number of employees is 20 and they are allowed to move between spaces. Staff should respect the 2-metre distance rule between themselves and towards students, but wear a mask otherwise. The rules of social distansing and wearing masks are not applied to students. For the school events attendance of outsiders is prohibited. Sports outside of school are prohibited

description: The national commissioner of the Icelandic police raises the alert level of the response to COVID-19 to emergency phase on March 6th, following the confirmation of the first transmissions of the virus within Iceland. description: From 24th January 2020, passengers arriving at Keflavik Airport will receive a message stating that if they have a sign of a respiratory infection and have been in Wuhan China for the past 14 days or have been in contact with individuals with a suspected or confirmed infection, they must undergo a medical assessment at Keflavik Airport. The continuation of operations is determined by the medical assessment, but isolation will be possible. Asymptomatic passengers who have been in Wuhan China for the past 14 days or have been in contact with individuals with suspected or confirmed infection will also be asked to report. These individuals can expect to be quarantined for a few days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
"From 24 February 2021, tourists from Greenland will be exempt from the requirement to present a certificate of negative PCR testing, screening and quarantine for COVID-19 upon arrival in Iceland.

The condition for the exemption is that the tourist has not visited a country or area that is classified as a risk area 14 days before arrival in Iceland."

description: From 2nd March 2020, The Medical Director of Health, the Chief Epidemiologist and the Civil Defense want to appeal to healthcare professionals as well as other staff working on COVID-19 preparedness to postpone all trips abroad as much as possible while clarifying the extent of the epidemic. This request is made to meet the likely strain on the health care system, which may be due on the one hand to an increase in cases and on the other hand to an increase in the number of health care workers in quarantine. Employees are asked to discuss matters further with their superiors as needed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 9th March 2020, ski resorts in the Alps are now a defined risk area for the virus that causes COVID-19 disease. This was decided by the epidemiologist in consultation with the National Commissioner of Police. The areas in question are in four countries; Austria, Switzerland, Germany and France. These areas are in addition to the aforementioned risk areas  China, South Korea, Iran and Italy as well as Ischgl in Austria. travelers from these areas who have traveled since the 29th of February 2020 should quarantine for 14 days.

description:
Starting on June 15, the icelandic government gives arriving tourists three options to chose of. 1. staying in quarantine for 14 days, 2. being screened for the novel coronavirus at Keflavík International Airport
or 3. presenting a certificate of recent screening, approved by Icelandic health authorities. 
The samples will analyzed at the lab of the Department of Microbiology at Landspítali National University Hospital (Reykjavik). Results should be available within five hours. The maximum number of samples taken and analyzed a day is expected to be 1,000. UPDATE: The icelandic government decided to let incoming tourists chose between 3 options for protection against Corona, starting at June15.

description: Starting 1 July 2020, passengers who choose to be tested on arrival will be charged a fee of ISK 11,000 if paid on site, but ISK 9000 if paid in advance. Icelandic authorities started offering testing on arrival on 15 June. Border testing will continue in the coming weeks, but the need for testing will be evaluated regularly. Information on testing fees and payments  - People who need to be tested more than twice in a 30-day period will be able to apply for a refund for the amount exceeding the monthly cap of testing fees, which is ISK 22000 per person per month. - Passengers arriving outside of business hours on a non-commercial flight can request to be tested on-site for a fee of up to ISK 30000.  - Children born in 2005 or later are exempt from testing and quarantine. - Those who choose to pay the screening fee in advance  lower fee  can do so online through a payment processing site. Payment must be made at least one day prior to arrival.  - Those who pay at the border  higher fee  can pay by cash or credit card. Cash payments will be subject to a fixed rate in several currencies, independent of the daily exchange rate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: from 13 July 2020 Icelandic citizens and residents of iceland who choose to be tested at the border would be required to self-quarantine for five days and undergo a secon test, free or charge, to eliminate risk of a false-negative result. as before, it will be possible to choose to self-quarantine for 14 days instead of undergoing a test at the border.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Minister of Justice has decided to extend the travel restrictions imposed by the EU and Schengen states while lifting restrictions for residents of fourteen non-EEA and Schengen states as of July 15, in line with the decision of EU Member States. The new regulation also states that the travel restrictions do not apply to citizens and residents of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican. The travel restrictions do not apply to EEA or EFTA citizens or those with valid residence permits or other rights of residence in an EEA or EFTA state, and their relatives. Furthermore, the restrictions do not apply to individuals with demonstratable residence in one of the following fourteen states when travelling to Iceland from their respective state of residence.  The fourteen states are  Algeria; Australia; Canada; Georgia; Japan; Montenegro; Morocco; New Zealand; Rwanda; Serbia; South Korea; Thailand; Tunisia; Uruguay. The list will be revised regularly.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description:
Update: From August 19 2020, all passengers arriving in Iceland must choose a 14-day quarantine OR a double COVID-testing procedure along with quarantine for 5-6 days. 
The first COVID test is at the border on arrival and the second by the primary healthcare service 5-6 days later. In between the 2 tests, arrivals must go into quarantine. UPDATE: From August 19 2020, all passengers arriving in Iceland must choose a 14-day quarantine OR a double COVID-testing procedure along with quarantine for 5-6 days. 
The first COVID test is at the border on arrival and the second by the primary healthcare service 5-6 days later. In between the 2 tests, arrivals must go into quarantine.

description: In Iceland, from 27 October 2020, the Minister of Tourism, Industry, and Innovation, the Minister of Justice and the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs have put in place measures to enable non-EEA foreign nationals to reside in Iceland for up to six months and telework for foreign companies. With the measure, those foreign citizens, who are exempt from the visa requirements, will be allowed to apply for a long-term visa in Iceland for teleworkers and bring their families without having to move their legal domicile to the country or obtain Icelandic ID numbers.

description: The Icelandic government declared that from 27th August 2020, foreign nationals, who will not be able to leave Iceland before 10 September 2020, can only extend their stay here without a residence permit or visa if they are issued a permission to stay upon being registered at the Directorate of Immigration. UPDATE: Foreign nationals, who were legally staying in Iceland prior to 20 March 2020 and have been unable to return to their home countries due to travel restrictions, quarantine or isolation, were permitted to stay in Iceland without a residence permit or visa until 10 November 2020, upon being registered at the Directorate of Immigration. The permission to stay without a residence permit or visa will not be extended again and such stays beyond 10 November 2020 may result in an expulsion. This policy ends 10 November 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Minister of Health of Iceland has decided that testing of travelers for COVID-19 at Iceland's borders is to be free of charge, on a temporary basis, from 1 December 2020 until 31 January 2021. This is in line with recommendations from the Chief Epidemiologist. The aim of the move is to encourage people to be tested rather than to commit to a period in quarantine, so reducing the likelihood that they will bring the infection with them into the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: All countries

description: New border measures will come into force on February 19, 2021  which requires all arriving passengers in Iceland to present a negative PCR taken within 72 hours of their time of departure to Iceland.This is in addition to the current system of double screening, that also requires all arriving passengers to submit to a PCR test upon arrival, followed by a 5-day quarantine and a second PCR test. Those who provide valid proof of having been vaccinated against COVID-19 are not required to provide a PCR-test prior to boarding and are also exempt from screening and quarantine measures at the border. The same applies to those who can provide proof of prior infection.

description: From 26 March 2021, Commercial flights to and from Iceland remain very limited. Travel restrictions apply to all third-country citizens. Citizens of Iceland,  EEA/EFTA citizens, or relatives of Icelandic/EEA/EFTA citizens are exempt. Further exemptions are granted for essential travel.    Third-country nationals traveling to Iceland are required to pre-register before departure; provide proof of a negative PCR test; take two tests to screen for the presence of COVID-19 after arrival in Iceland, with a mandatory 5-6 day quarantine between each test.

description: From 10 May 2021, Only Icelandic citizens and their families, people with permanent residency in Iceland, residents of the EEA/EFTA area,* citizens of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino or Vatican City can travel to Iceland. Others need to apply for exemptions in advance. In all cases, however, travellers must present a negative PCR COVID-19 test, vaccination certificate, or previous infection certificate to be admitted into the country after which they will be monitored.   *Notably, until 31 May 2021, all foreigners who arrive from or have stayed in, for more than 24 hours within the last 14 days, an area where the 14-day incidence rate of infection is higher than 700 persons out of every 100 000 inhabitants, or where sufficient information about the area is not available, are forbidden from entering Iceland. The ban applies to all foreigners, including citizens of the EEA and EFTA, as well as all citizens of third countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)

description:
from 3rd June 2021, the Faroe islands again risk zone due to covid-19
the chief epidemiologist has decided to put the faroe islands back on the list of defined risk areas covid-19 due to the growing incidence of infections in that country. tourists coming from the faroe islands are therefore no longer exempt from border control measures and the same rules therefore apply to them and generally apply to passengers arriving in iceland. all countries and regions in the world except greenland are considered risk areas due to covid-19."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 22 June 2021, there are no travel restrictions to travel to Iceland on the citizens and permanent residents of EEA/EFTA countries (as well as Andorra, Monaco, San Marino or the Vatican) but travellers who have not been vaccinated or previously infected with covid-19 are subject to testing and quarantine requirements.  Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless the provide a valid reason.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Proof of COVID-19 vaccination
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_who_gen: People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19

description: From 6 July 2021, All travelers – regardless of origin – are welcome to visit Iceland if they can show either a certificate of full vaccination against COVID, or a certificate of previous COVID infection

type_sub_cat: Proof of COVID-19 vaccination
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 19 July 2021, in Iceland, testing stopped at the border for those presenting valid vaccination certificates. Testing is also no longer required in children born from 2005 onwards. These groups no longer need to show a negative PCR test result upon arrival in Iceland.     Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless they provide a valid reason.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As of 27 July 2021, the Icelandic government states that all vaccinated persons and those that can present a certificate of a prior COVID-19 infection must present a negative PCR or antigen (rapid) test that is no more than 72 hours old before departure to Iceland. Unvaccinated individuals will continue to be required to present negative PCR test results no more than 72 hours old and undergo double PCR screening with a five-day quarantine in between.    Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless they provide a valid reason.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From 17 August 2021, All travellers who enter Iceland, and are considered to have close ties within the Icelandic community, will need to undergo an additional covid-19 test upon arrival in Iceland. They are not required to quarantine, but are asked to limit their interactions in the first few days after arrival.    Vaccinated passengers (and those with a prior infection) born in 2004 or earlier, must present a negative PCR or antigen test (not older than 72 hours) prior to boarding a vessel to Iceland. They are not required to be tested at the border or to quarantine upon arrival.    Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless the provide a valid reason.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Negative COVID-19 Test

description: Iceland launched an app that uses GPS to locate people who may have been in close contact with confirmed COVID-19 patients. A message containing a download link for the app will be sent to all Icelanders; downloading it and then agreeing to disclose GPS data are both voluntary, but for it to work as intended 60% will need to opt in. The app will register all nearby phones, so that if an individual gets infected the authorities will have an accurate record of everyone who came into contact with them and how long, and can send alerts to those who may have been exposed ordering them to quarantine. The app will be launched from April 1, 2020
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On mAy 14, 2020, The Ministry of Education, Science and Culture and the National Association of Icelandic students annlunced about the implementation of 'A joint attitude survey' in order to get a clear picture of the situation for universities and its development this summer. The survey will be sent to all university students. The survey is about employment, summer study and student well-being, it is anonymous and participants give their consent for the Ministry and LÍS to publish full results on the status of students.

description:
In Iceland, from July 13th, for Icelandic residents and citizens returning home have to on arrival complete a period of “heimkomusmitgát” (home-coming contagion caution). This means will they be tested for COVID-19 at the border and they will also be required to undergo a second free PCR test at a local healthcare centre four to five days later. Until they get the results of the second test Icelanders should:

Maintain two-metre distancing
Only attend gatherings of up to ten people
Avoid high-risk individuals e.g. the elderly
Avoid physical contact

Heimkomusmitgát is not the same as quarantine; Icelanders will be  permitted to use public transport, go to shops and meet family and friends whilst they await test results.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 16, 2020, The Minsitry of Health of Iceland have announced that front-line healthcare workers will receive a one-off payment to reflect their service. The bill is expected to be paid out on July 1. The surcharges amount to a total of ISK 1.0 billion through salary related expenses. The estimated number of staff who can receive these payments is about 3000 people, which is the number of employees who have at some point had to wear protective suits, as well as more staff who have stood on the front lines.

description: Icelands Chief Epidemiologist and deCODE Genetics start collecting blood samples from the general public in order to help determine how widespread COVID-19 infection has been within the Icelandic population on May 4, 2020. Donating blood for the survey is voluntarily. People undergoing blood tests for other reasons will also be asked to donate a sample. The blood samples will also be tested for antibodies. Those, who give blood will be notified of their test results.

description: Starting on May 12, 2020, The Department of Gerontology and Virology at the National Institute of Health has begun to measure antibodies against the virus. This project collects only samples from individuals coming for blood tests for other reasons at present.

description: According to April 21, 2020, announcement of the Government of Iceland, economic support on the following issue will take an effect. Economic support resources should focus on mental health with remote medical services being strengthened and new campaign against domestic violence. Special measures will be taken to support vulnerable groups, work against violence, counteract social isolation among the elderly and disabled, support job-seekers, and ensure that children from low-income families have the opportunity to participate in recreational activities.

type_text: The policy is about economic support and therefore, is coded under the category "other". The article just seems to list off things that money will be allocated to without saying how these things will actually be achieved. So the best to consider it an economic policy and code this whole thing under the category "other".

description: On 6th April, 2020 The Office of the Medical Director of Health has advised avoiding the usage of alcohol and tobacco as a remedy for stress as alcohol consumption is associated with a negative health effect on the immune system and general health. Alcohol consumption can also reduce recovery after infections or operations.

description: The definition of criteria for determining whether countries or areas are considered high-risk areas has been revised. The definition of high-risk areas affects which individuals must quarantine in a quarantine facility upon arrival in Iceland. description: As hitherto, an epidemiologist may permit persons, individually or in groups, who are subject to the quarantine requirement on entering Iceland in order to work or perform specific tasks to undergo employment-related quarantine instead of quarantine in their home or other premises. Under employment-related quarantine, the person is permitted to travel to and from the workplace during the quarantine period. The rules on employment-related quarantine remain unchanged from August 19, 2020.

description: on 11th September 2020, the Iceland health minister has also approved the proposal to change home quarantine rules within Iceland for those who come into contact with infected individuals. description: All permitted arrivals can choose to either self-isolate for 14 days or submit to two COVID-19 tests. description: Iceland sets ut guidelines for restaurants and tour operators from March 14. Restaurants were asked to re-arrange their seating to at least two meters between seats, asking that only families and other groups in regular close contact would be seated together, that menus would be washed between each use, and that hand sanitation be available at entry and encourage guests to use them. Tour operators have been asked to offer hand sanitiser at every entry point and encourage passengers to use them, to use back doors if available, make sure that passengers embark and disembark with enough space in between each, and skip using every other row to ensure proper space between passengers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

Otherwise, the general rule of the two-meter social distancing between individuals still applies. In circumstances where the two-meter distance cannot be maintained face masks should be worn. Colleges and universities will be allowed to maintain one-meter social distance between individuals without face masks. Common equipment and surfaces shall be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis placed on personal hygienic measures and individual responsibility. UPDATE: Starting on August 21, 2020, in all secondary school and university buildings, social distancing of 1 meter between individuals should be applied. In situations where the principle of intimacy cannot be enforced, such as practical teaching, art education and clinical learning, a face mask covering the mouth and nose should be worn. Both teachers and students should wear a mask.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting on August 21, 2020, in all secondary school buildings, social distancing of 1 meter between individuals should be applied. In situations where the principle of intimacy cannot be enforced, such as practical teaching, art education and clinical learning, a face mask covering the mouth and nose should be worn. Both teachers and students should wear a mask. Educational processes shall be organized so that each student interacts with as few as possible. Students should be distributed to permanent entrances to a school building as far as possible and corridors shall be a travel space. Permanent groups and classes should be avoided as far as possible mixing with other students. All non-teaching events should be cancelled. 
Common equipment/contact surfaces should be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis should also be placed on individual antiseptic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: According to the policy on August 21, 2020, the rules on mass limits and proximity limits do not apply to children born in 2005 and later. Preschools (i.e. kindergartens) maintain school work on a condition that staff who are involved in school buildings may have at least a 1-metre proximity restriction between themselves without the use of face masks. Only one parent may accompany a child on a condition that they do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and they shall observe at least a 1 meter proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Preschool administration may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees and parents entering kindergartens, such as for freight, care should be taken to a 2-metre proximity restriction. Disinfection measures should be taken after each day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Iceland announces that people will have to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas starting from the 24th of March.
UPDATE: The Icelandic government announces that the original 2 metre social distancing rule has been relaxed to 1 metre. This will take affect on September 7. UPDATE: The ‘social distancing’ rule will be relaxed from the original 2 metre distance to 1 metre.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Starting from October 5, 2020, the maximum number of gatherings for colleges and universities is 30 people. The restrictions do not apply to children born in 2005 and later. The distance limit will remain 1 meter and in situations where this is not possible, it is mandatory to wear face masks.

description:
The Minister of Health has accepted the recommendations for stricter limits on the size of gatherings in the metropolitan area. The policy takes effect on October 7, 2020. The restrictions announced on 5 October remain unchanged in other parts of the country, this policy is related only to metropolitan area. The restrictions announced here will remain in force until 19 October. 
The metropolitan area includes: Reykjavík, Seltjarnarnesbær, Mosfellsbær, Kjósarhreppur, Hafnarfjarðarkaupstaður, Garðabær and Kópavogur.
Students in schools (except pupils born in or after 2005) need to keep social distancing of 2 metres.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Preschools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter the sshool building unless it is necessary. For adjustment periods the presence of a single parent (and only) parent for a child must be organised such that parents do not use common equipment in the school and they must maintain the 2-metre social distancing rule among themselves and between themselves and employees. School management may require parents to wear masks. Disinfection should be taken after each day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Primary schools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. This regulations are applied to after school centres, community centres and sports activities in primary schools. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter school buildings except when absolutely necessary. Disinfection should be taken after each day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings in Iceland remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Secondary schools may continue schoolwork on condition that students and staff can maintain at least 2 metre social distancing. Mixing students between groups is forbidden but teachers and employesses are allowed to go between groups. The restriction on the number of people, or mixing groups may be departed in shared premises as entrance, foyes, and restrooms if face masks are used. Under specific circumstances (practical classes, art classes), students and teachers must use face masks. Non-teaching events should be banned. Physical contact is permitted only during sports training sessions and competitions but in changing rooms 2 metres distance should be kept. Share contact surfaces/equipment needs to be disinfected daily.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Preschools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter the sshool building unless it is necessary. Sports, youth and leisure events for children/pre-school age are prohibited either inside or outside the pre-school premises.

description: According to the new regulations on October 21st, 2020, in metropolitan area, all sports and leisure activities for children of pre-school (kindergarten) age and junior-school age, including school swimming lessons, which involve physical contact, are prohibited. Sports and leisure activities that do not involve physical contact are permitted. All sports and leisure activities that do not involve mixing between groups over and above that which takes place in the classroom, e.g. breaktime activities or physical education classes in schools, are therefore permitted. Gatherings are limited to 20 people, and the distance of 2 meters should be applied. During the sessions participants may not exchange equipment and all equipment shall be disinfected between sessions. Usage of shared equipments are prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Sports, youth and leisure events for children/pre-school age are prohibited either inside or outside the pre-school premises.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On November 02, 2020, new regulations for primary level schools.
Grades 1–4: Pupils are exempted from the 2-metre social distancing rule and are not required to wear face masks. Social gathering limit is 50 people. The same rules apply for after-school leisure centres for children in Grades 1-4.
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. The rules on group sizes and mixing of groups may be set aside in common areas in schools, providing that pupils in Grades 5–10, and the staff, wear face masks. Staff are permitted to move between groups and limit of gathering is 10 people. Staff needs to keep distance rule of 2 metres. Social events, sport activities are prohibited.
Pupil are exempted of mask wearing and 2 metres distance rules.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On November 02, 2020, new regulations for secondary school level. Grades 5–10: Social gathering limit is 25 pupils. The social distancing rule of 2-metres should be kept. In case the distance rule can not be kept, face masks should be worn. Staff must also observe the distance rule and use face masks when it is needed. 
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. The rules on group sizes and mixing of groups may be set aside in common areas in schools, providing that pupils in Grades 5–10, and the staff, wear face masks. Staff are permitted to move between groups and limit of gathering is 10 people. Staff needs to keep distance rule of 2 metres. Social events, sport activities are prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 2, 2020 announcement, the maximum number of people is 25 for the first year of school at the upper secondary schools; and 10 for upper secondary schools, universities and music schools. The 2-metre social distance rule and the obligation to wear face masks are applied. Mixing of groups of students is not permitted during teaching; teaching and other staff may, however, move between groups. In specific cases (practical classes, art teaching and clinical training) when the distance can not be kept, both teachers and students should wear face masks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On November 02, 2020, new regulations for primary level schools.
Grades 1–4: Pupils are exempted from the 2-metre social distancing rule and are not required to wear face masks. Social gathering limit is 50 people. The same rules apply for after-school leisure centres for children in Grades 1-4.
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. The rules on group sizes and mixing of groups may be set aside in common areas in schools, providing that pupils in Grades 5–10, and the staff, wear face masks. Staff are permitted to move between groups and limit of gathering is 10 people. Staff needs to keep distance rule of 2 metres. Social events, sport activities are prohibited.
Pupil are exempted of mask wearing and 2 metres distance rules. UPDATE: According to the data on November 18, 2020, in Iceland, rehearsals, sports, youth- and after-school activities for children of primary-school age are all now allowed again, outdoors and indoors. There are no limits set on mixing between groups. Children in years five to seven are now also exempt from face mask rules.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 2, 2020 announcement, the maximum number of people is 25 for the first year of school at the upper secondary schools; and 10 for upper secondary schools, universities and music schools. The distance rule and the usage of face masks rule remain the same. Mixing of groups of students is not permitted during teaching; teaching and other staff may, however, move between groups. In specific cases (practical classes, art teaching and clinical training) when the distance can not be kept, both teachers and students should wear face masks. UPDATE: As of November 18, 2020, personalised services that require closer contact than two metres are allowed again, with mandatory face masks. Students in upper secondary schools, universities (usually ages 16 to 20) can gather in groups of up to 25 (including staff), instead of the previous limit of 10. Staff and students must still wear face masks whenever it is not possible to maintain the two-metre rule.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Iceland Minister of Health on November 20, 2020, announced that music schools are permitted to conduct individual lessons with a 2-metre proximity restriction between staff and students. In case when the distance rule cannot be applied, both students and employees shall wear a face mask. The maximum number will be comparable to that in primary schools; 25 for the older students, i.e. in grades 5-10 and 50 for younger students. The two-metre rule applies to students in grades 8-10, but if it needs to be deviated from, face masks should be used. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Non-employees who come to music schools, such as for freight, shall wear face masks. Buildings should be disinfected after each day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Under new regulations from the Minister of Health on December 22, 2020, some relaxations will be made in the measures against Covid-19 applying in schools and universities in the new year. In pre-schools and junior schools up to 20 staff may occupy the same area, and may move between groups. The distance rule remains the same (2 meters), whenever it can not be kept, face masks should be worn. In junior schools, in shared areas (canteens), the number restrictions may be ignored, providing that staff use face-masks. These rules will also apply to after-school activity centres, organised sports events, youth activities and leisure activities, and to the operations of social centres. In upper-secondary schools gathering ban is up to 30 pupils and staff may occupy the same area. Pupils may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. In universities gathering ban is up to 50 students and staff may occupy each teaching or study area. Mixing between these groups of students will not be permitted, though staff may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. Music lessons for children in pre-schools and junior school are permitted, observing the same rules as apply to each school level respectively. For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Under new regulations from the Minister of Health on December 22, 2020, some relaxations will be made in the measures against Covid-19 applying in schools and universities in the new year. In pre-schools and junior schools up to 20 staff may occupy the same area, and may move between groups. The distance rule remains the same (2 meters), whenever it can not be kept, face masks should be worn. In junior schools, in shared areas (canteens), the number restrictions may be ignored, providing that staff use face-masks. These rules will also apply to after-school activity centres, organised sports events, youth activities and leisure activities, and to the operations of social centres. In upper-secondary schools gathering ban is up to 30 pupils and staff may occupy the same area. Pupils may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. In universities gathering ban is up to 50 students and staff may occupy each teaching or study area. Mixing between these groups of students will not be permitted, though staff may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. Music lessons for children in pre-schools and junior school are permitted, observing the same rules as apply to each school level respectively. For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. The policy will take effect from February 24 until  April 30, 2021. In pre-schools social gatherings limit is 50 people and the rule of social distancing of 1 metre should be kept. Whenever it is not possible to keep social distance of 1 metre employees should use face masks. Employees are allowed to move between groups only if they implement the highest level of infection prevention measures. Children are exempt from the limit on social gatherings, social distancing and wearing masks rules.

description: Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. description: On February 23rd, 2021, the Government of Iceland announced new loosening on COVID-19 measures. The general limit on gatherings will be raised from 20 to 50. A general limit of 150 people within confined areas will apply to higher level schooling, including universities. A one-meter distancing rule will apply in schools and masks will only be required where it is not possible to guarantee the distancing rule. Higher level education returning to normalcy starting from February 24, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Education

description:
Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. The policy will take effect from March 25, 2021 and shall remain in force up to 31 March 2021. Preschools may maintain school work in school buildings with a 2-metre proximity limit between staff. Whenever the social distance of 2 metres cannot be ensured, masks shouls be worn. Employees are not obliged to wear face masks when communicating with preschoolers. There should be no more than 10 adults in each space. Children are exempt from mass gathering and social distancing limitations. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Adaptation periods should be organized in a way that parents do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and keep at least a 2-metre proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Only one parent accompanies the child in an adjustment.
Preschool administrators may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees entering kindergartens (i.e. service staff, freight) should keep 2-metre proximity restriction and wear face masks.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Restaurants may stay open until 10 p.m., with a maximum of 20 guests in each separate area; details of all guests shall be registered and they shall be served when seated in numbered seats. Alcoholic beverages shall be served to seated customers. New guests may be admitted until 9 p.m. Shops may admit 5 persons for every 10 m2 of their floor area, to a maximum of 50 persons. Up to 20 members of staff may be present in the same area as customers. The 2-m distancing rule shall be observed, and face masks shall be worn from 24 march 2021
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Minister of Health, the Ministry of Education, Science and Culture on March 31, 2021 announced regulations regarding the operation of schools. Starting from April 1 through April 15, the following regulations in colleges are applied:
The maximum number of students and staff in a space is 30. A 2-metre proximity restriction should be maintained between students and staff, but a mask should be worn otherwise. The mixing of students between groups is permitted and staff are allowed to move between spaces. Events related to work or social life in secondary school shall be governed by the provisions on performing arts in the Regulation on restrictions on epidemic gatherings.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education

description:

The maximum number of students is 50 and mixing between groups within the same school is permitted. The maximum number of employees is 20 and they are allowed to move between spaces. Staff should respect the 2-metre distance rule between themselves and towards students, but wear a mask otherwise. The rules of social distansing and wearing masks are not applied to students. For the school events attendance of outsiders is prohibited. Sports outside of school are prohibited

description:
Starting from May 5, 2021, policy on the restriction of school activities due to stricter infection prevention measures takes effect. In nursery schools and day-care parents (i.e. preschools and kindergartens) limit on gatherings is 20 people and they need to keep distance of 1 metre. Whenever a 1-metre distance limit can not be kept, and when employees travel between areas, masks should be worn. Employees are permitted to transfer between the groups only if the highest level of infection prevention measures are implemented. 
Children are exempt from the social distansing, mask wearing, social gathering limit and mixing groups restrictions.

In universities the following rules should be applied. Limit on gatherings of students and employees per each separate room is 50 and minimum distance of 1 meter should be kept. Whenever the social distancing rule ccan not be applied, face masks should be worn. Employees can move between groups only if the highest level of infection prevention control is implemented and disinfection measures are employed between groups.  Mixing of students is not allowed. In shared ares of the school building it is possible to deviate limit on gatherings if face masks are used. Physical education lessons are allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: Starting on May 10 until May26, 2021, stricter infection prevention measures are applied for schools. In nursery schools and day-care parents (kindergartens, preschools), limit on gatherings for employees in each area is 50, and they should keep social distancing rule of 1 metre. Whenever it is not possible to keep distance, and they transfer between groups, masks should be worn. Transfer between areas is allowed only if the highest level of infection prevention control is implemented. Limit on gatherings, mask wearing and socail distansing rules are not applied to children. Also, there are no restrictions on interactions between and the number of nursery school children.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: Starting on May 10 until May26, 2021, stricter infection prevention measures are applied for schools. In primary schools and after-school activities, limit on gatherings for employees in each area is 50, and 100 for children. Employees should keep social distancing rule of 1 metre. Whenever it is not possible to keep distance, and they transfer between groups, masks should be worn. Transfer between areas is allowed only if the highest level of infection prevention control is implemented. Mask wearing and socail distansing rules are not applied to children. In shared areas of school buildings restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks. Physical education and school swimming lessons are allowed and mixing between groups is also allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
